acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours EC50=1.66mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (CERI Hazard Data, 2002).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of 800mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2000-22 (2001)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 260mg/kg, representing the lower of the two testing data, 260mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2000-22 (2001)) and 300mg/kg (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A3 by ACGIH (2001) and Group 2B by IARC (1999).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 83% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=0.88 (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was claasified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though classified as "flammable" by ICSC (2004)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests), described in CERI Hazard Data 2000-22 (2001), NTP DB (Access on March 2006) and IARC 71 (1999).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 510degC (ICSC, 2004)

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on the ovary and the development of the filial generation, described in MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003) (though no data are available on parental toxicity).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available (melting point: 105degC (ICSC, 2004), test temperature: 140degC).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "rabbits exhibited discharge, moderate conjunctivitis and corneal opacity after exposure. At 72 hours, severe conjunctivitis, iritis and diffuse corneal opacity were found. Conical cornea due to angiogenesis was observed on day 14." Also based on the description in MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003) of the human health effects: "corrosive to the eye." The substance is thus considered "corrosive."

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on 24-hour skin irritation tests in rabbits (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "The substance produced mild to moderate erythema and mild edema when applied to intact skin, while necrosis when applied to abraded skin." The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (hematopoietic system, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "degenerative lesion of the renal tubules" (PATTY (4th, 1999)), "hypofunction of the hematopoietic system/liver/kidneys" (IUCLID (2000)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (central nervous system),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (central nervous system)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "irritation of the skin/respiratory tract/gastrointestinal tract," "the substance adversely affects the central nervous system, causing suppression, spasm, respiratory failure and elevated blood pressure" (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2  (2003)), and the evidence from animal studies including "irritation, toxicosis manifested as tremor" (PATTY (4th,1999)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.
